questions.text: A woman diagnosed with DCIS underwent surgery and is now posted for adjuvant radiotherapy with external beam radiotherapy. Which of the following isotopes is commonly used for the same?
questions.solution:
Cobalt-60 (Co-60 ) isotope is used for external beam radiotherapy (EBRT).

External beam radiotherapy is given as follows:

  • Cobalt machine - Co-60 produces gamma rays. It emits radiation of energy 1.25 MeV.
  • LINAC (linear accelerator) - X-ray beams are generated to provide ionising radiation.

The energy spectrum used in radiotherapy is classified as follows:

  • Orthovoltage - 200-500kV x-rays are produced. It is used to treat skin conditions. 
  • Megavoltage - 1-25 MV x-rays are produced. These are used in modern radiotherapy.

questions.text: The most common cause of β0-thalassemia is _____________
questions.solution:
Chain terminator mutations are the most common cause of β0-thalassemia.

There are two subtypes in this mutations, one creates a new stop codon within an exon and the other introduces small insertions or deletions that shift the mRNA reading frames.

Related Pearl: Thalassemia syndromes

Normally each individual carries 4 functional alpha chain genes and 2 functional beta chain genes. Alpha and beta-thalassemia are inherited disorders in which there is reduced production of alpha-globin or beta-globin chains, respectively.

  • Alpha thalassemia: Gene deletion is the most common cause of reduced α-chain synthesis.
  • Beta +- thalassemia: The most common cause is splicing mutation.
  • Beta 0- thalassemia: Chain terminator mutations are the most common cause.

The table below describes the features of typical thalassemia syndromes:

Alpha thalassemias  Hb Barts HbH disease  Minor Silent carrier
Genotype (- - / - - )

(α -/ - -)

or

(α* -/ - -)

(α -/α -)

(α α/- -)

Hemoglobin electro-phoresis Hb Barts (γ globin tetramers); Hb Portland (embryonic hemoglobin); no HbF, HbA, or HbA2 HbH (beta-globin tetramers -up to 30%); HbA2 (up to 4%) Hb Barts (3 to 8%) Normal

"-" denotes deletion of an alpha gene and "α" denotes normal alpha gene and "α* " refers to a mutant alpha chain gene.

Beta thalassemias Major (transfusion-dependent) Intermedia (non-transfusion-dependent) Minor (also called trait or carrier)

Hemoglobin electrophoresis HbA2 (5% or more); HbF (up to 95%); no HbA HbA2 (4% or more); HbF (up to 50%) HbA2 (4% or more); HbF (up to 5%)

β0 refers to no beta-globin production; β+ refers to decreased beta-globin production.

questions.text:
Which of the following are causes of drug-induced pemphigus?
  1. Penicillamine
  2. Sodium valproate
  3. Penicillin
  4. Isoniazid
  5. Captopril
questions.solution:
Sodium valproate and isoniazid do not cause drug-induced pemphigus. The commonly implicated drugs include:

  • Penicillamine (most common)
  • ACE inhibitors 
  • Antibiotics - penicillins, cephalosporins, rifampicin
  • Piroxicam
  • Glibenclamide
  • Phenobarbital
  • Aspirin

Drug-induced pemphigus usually occurs after 1 year of taking the drug. It is more common in individuals with other associated autoimmune conditions.

Note: Common drugs (mnemonic - PCR) are penicillamine, captopril, rifampicin.

questions.text: What is the most common complication of bracing in scoliosis?
questions.solution:
Poor compliance due to discomfort and poor appearance is the most common complication of bracing.

Other complications of bracing include:

  • Skin breakdown
  • Excessive sweating
  • Allergic skin reaction
  • Increased gastric pressure
  • Spontaneous sternum fracture

questions.text: The most common cause of neuropathic (Charcot’s) joint is ________
questions.solution:
Diabetes is the most common cause of Charcot's joint (arthropathy).

Charcot's arthropathy is a neurodegenerative process that threatens both the function and viability of the limb. It progresses through the phases of bony destruction, resorption, and deformity.

Other causes include

  • Syphilis
  • Heavy metal poisoning
  • Alcoholic or congenital neuropathy
  • Leprosy
  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Idiopathic

questions.text: What is the most common arrhythmia encountered in pregnancy?
questions.solution: The most common arrhythmia seen in reproductive-aged women is paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia.

questions.text: Which among the following is the most common fingerprint pattern?
questions.solution:
Loops are the most common fingerprint pattern encountered. 

Patterns of fingerprints:

  • Loops (60-70%)
    • Radial
    • Ulnar
  • Whorls 
    • Concentric
    • Spiral
    • Double spiral
    • Almond shaped
  • Arches 
    • Plain
    • Tented
  • Composite
    • Central pocket loop
    • Lateral pocket loop
    • Twinned loop
    • Accidentals

The image given below shows the different patterns of fingerprints.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of perioperative vision loss?
questions.solution:
Ischemic optic neuropathy is the most common cause of perioperative vision loss.

It is usually seen after spine surgeries in the prone position, radical neck dissections and following cardiopulmonary bypass.

Symptoms: Reduced visual acuity, rarely complete blindness; usually presents on awakening from anesthesia.

Preoperative risk factors: 

  • Diabetes, hypertension
  • Smoking
  • Coronary artery disease.

Intraoperative risk factors: 

  • Anaemia
  • Hypotension
  • Prone position
  • Prolonged duration of surgery

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common type of tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF)?

choices.text: Proximal TEF with distal esophageal atresia

questions.solution:
The most common type of tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF) is esophageal atresia with distal TEF (also known as type C). 

It occurs due to the defective formation of the tracheoesophageal septum. There is an abnormal connection (fistula) between the esophagus and the trachea. These defects occur in approximately 1/3000 births. The condition is commonly associated with esophageal atresia. 

TEF can be grossly classified into 5 types, types A to E, as shown in the image below:

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common type of delusion seen in schizophrenia?
questions.solution:
The most common delusion in schizophrenia is the delusion of persecution.  

These persecutory fears of the patient can range from transient doubts to profound convictions that people are plotting to have them tortured or killed.

Related Pearl: Types of delusions

THE TYPES OF DELUSIONS

Delusion of control

False belief that a person’s will, thoughts, or feelings are being controlled by external forces.

Delusion of grandeur or Megalomania 

Exaggerated conception of one’s importance, power, or identity.

Delusion of infidelity or morbid jealousy or Othello syndrome

False belief that one’s lover is unfaithful. Sometimes called pathological jealousy.

Delusion of love or erotomania

False belief that another person is in love with them. In De Clerambault syndrome, the woman believes that a man, frequently older and of higher status, is in love with her.

Delusion of misidentification 

Capgras syndrome: Belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double i.e. an impostor.

Fregoli syndrome: Person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Nihilistic delusion 

False belief that oneself, others or the world, is non-existent or about to end. When nihilistic delusion is accompanied by ideas concerning bodily function failure e.g. putrefaction of intestine etc, it is called Cotard syndrome.

Delusion of infestation 

False belief that one is infested with small but visible organisms. As a monosymptomatic delusional disorder, this is called Ekbom syndrome. 

Delusion of persecution

The most common delusion. False belief of being harassed or persecuted.

Delusion of poverty

The person strongly believes they are financially incapacitated.

Delusion of reference

False belief that the behavior of others has a particular and unusual significance, usually of a negative nature. The person may falsely feel that others are talking about them (e.g. the people on television are talking to or about the person).  

Delusion of self-accusation

False feeling of remorse and guilt. Seen in depression with psychotic features.

questions.text: Which is the most widely used instrument to measure humidity?
questions.solution:
The most widely used instrument to measure humidity is the dry and wet bulb hygrometer.

Related Pearl: Humidity

Absolute humidity is the weight of water vapor in a unit volume of air and it is expressed as g/kg of air or g/m3 of air.

Relative humidity (RH):

  • It is the ratio of the actual water vapor content to the maximum water vapor content in the air required for saturation of air at a given temperature and pressure. It is expressed as a percentage.
  • RH = Actual water vapor content x 100/ Total water vapor content
  • Very low RH can cause skin problems, irritation of the mucous membranes of the nose and throat, and precipitation of infections. 

Dew point is the temperature to which air has to be cooled to achieve saturation given the pressure and constant moisture content

Measurement of humidity:

  • Dry and wet hygrometers - most widely used instrument
  • Sling or whirling psychrometers

The following image depicts a whirling psychrometer:

The following image depicts an Assmann psychrometer:

The following image depicts a dry and wet hygrometer:

questions.text: What is the most common cause of secondary headache?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of secondary headache is a systemic infection.

Causes of primary headache, in decreasing order:  

  • Tension-type headache
  • Migraine
  • Idiopathic stabbing
  • Exertional 
  • Cluster

Causes of secondary headache, in decreasing order:

  • Systemic infection
  • Head injury 
  • Vascular disorders 
  • Subarachnoid hemorrhage 
  • Brain tumor

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of blindness in India?
questions.solution: According to the National Survey on Blindness (2015-2019), cataract is the most common cause of blindness in India accounting for 66.2% of the total cases.

questions.text: Which is the most common congenital abnormality of urethra?
questions.solution:
Hypospadias occurs in around one in 200–300 male live births and is the most common congenital abnormality of the urethra.

Three characteristic features : 

  1. External meatus opens on the underside of the penis or the perineum.

  2. The ventral aspect of the prepuce is poorly developed (‘hooded prepuce’)

  3. There is a ventral deformity of the erect penis (chordee).

questions.text: The most common comorbid disorder in children with speech and language disorders is _________
questions.solution:
In children with speech and language disorders, the most common comorbid disorders were:

  • Attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD, 19 percent)
  • Anxiety disorders (10 percent)
  • Oppositional defiant disorder and conduct disorder (7 percent combined)

questions.text: What is the most common inflammatory myopathy in children?
questions.solution:
Dermatomyositis is the most common inflammatory myopathy in children.

Two types of dermatomyositis are known—juvenile and adult.

  Juvenile dermatomyositis Adult dermatomyositis
Age of onset  7 years 4th to 6th decade
Common associations

Calcinosis

Lipodystrophy

Cardiac and lung involvement

Underlying malignancy (15-25%)

Myositis-specific antibodies
Prognosis Better Worse

questions.text:
A sexually active woman presents with multiple lesions over her genital region as shown below. Which of the following organisms are implicated in this condition?
  1. HPV 16 
  2. HPV 11
  3. HPV 18
  4. HPV 6 
  5. HPV 31
questions.solution:
The given scenario and image are suggestive of genital warts. Human papillomavirus (HPV) 6 and 11 cause nearly all genital warts.

It is usually clinically diagnosed but if co-existing neoplasia is suspected then a biopsy is required. HPV serotyping is not required for routine diagnosis.

questions.text: The most common preventable cause of anesthetic mishaps is:
questions.solution:
The most common preventable cause of anesthetic mishaps is human error.

 Common human errors include:

  • Unrecognized breathing circuit disconnection
  • Mistaken drug administration
  • Airway mismanagement
  • Anesthesia machine misuse
  • Fluid mismanagement
  • Intravenous line disconnection

Equipment malfunctions that can cause preventable anesthetic accidents are:

  • Breathing circuit malfunction
  • Monitoring device malfunction
  • Ventilator dysfunction
  • Anesthesia machine malfunction
  • Faulty laryngoscope

Unpreventable mishaps include sudden death syndrome and fatal idiosyncratic drug reactions.

questions.text: There is an outbreak of chickenpox among the children at a daycare center. What is the most common extracutaneous site of involvement of this disease?
questions.solution:
The most common extracutaneous site of involvement by the varicella-zoster virus in children is the central nervous system.

Central nervous system (CNS) involvement is a benign complication of VZV infection in children and generally does not require hospitalization. They may develop acute cerebellar ataxia and meningeal inflammation around 21 days after the onset of the rash. The CSF findings include the presence of lymphocytes and elevated levels of protein. Other CNS manifestations include

  • Aseptic meningitis
  • Encephalitis
  • Transverse myelitis
  • Guillain-Barré syndrome

The most common infectious complication of varicella is secondary bacterial superinfection of the skin, which is caused by Streptococcus pyogenes or Staphylococcus aureus while the most common serious complication of varicella is varicella pneumonia.

Other options:

Option A: Hepatic involvement is common in chickenpox and is usually asymptomatic. It is characterized by elevated levels of liver enzymes, particularly aspartate and alanine aminotransferase. Reye’s syndrome may occur in children concomitantly treated with aspirin and hence is not used.

Option C: Chickenpox may involve the joints and cause arthritis as a complication.

Option D: Lung involvement is more common in adults than children and is more severe in pregnant women. The most common serious complication of varicella is varicella pneumonia.

questions.text: Which is the most common artery involved in Takayasu arteritis?
questions.solution:
The most common artery involved in Takayasu arteritis is the subclavian artery.

Patients present with pain, claudication, and weakness of the affected limb. The arterial pulse in the affected limb may be weak or absent.

The order of arteries affected in Takayasu arteritis is subclavian artery > common carotid artery > abdominal aorta > renal artery > aortic arch = vertebral > coeliac axis > iliac > pulmonary > coronary artery.

questions.text: The most common lens subluxation seen in Marfan's syndrome is __________
questions.solution:
Marfan’s syndrome is most commonly associated with superotemporal subluxation of lens.

Congenital subluxation of the lens is called ectopia lentis.

Types of ectopia lentis are as follows:

  • Simple type
  • Ectopia lentis et pupillae (pupil also displaced in opposite direction)
  • Ectopia lentis associated with syndromes
  • Marfan’s syndrome: Superotemporal subluxation of lens
  • Homocystinuria: Inferonasal subluxation of the lens
  • Weill–Marchesani: Downward, forward subluxation of the lens.
  • Ehler–Danlos syndrome: Blue sclera

questions.text: A woman was administered an intravenous opioid for managing postoperative pain. Within 5 minutes, she started developing severe redness and pruritus along the distribution of the vein into which the drug was injected. Which of the following drugs would be responsible for this?
questions.solution:
The clinical findings are suggestive of histamine release, which is common with the use of meperidine (pethidine) due to mast cell activation. 

Codeine, morphine, and hydromorphone are also associated with histamine release.

Fentanyl, alfentanil, and remifentanil do not lead to histamine release.

Related Pearl: High Yield Points in Opioids

  • Post thoracotomy pain managed by: IV fentanyl
  • Drug of choice for controlling severe pain in cancer patients: Morphine
  • Drug of choice for OPD analgesia: Alfentanyl
  • Most potent: sufentanyl
  • Shortest acting opioid-remifentanyl

questions.text: The MRI of a woman presenting with recurrent headaches is given below. Microscopy of the resected tumor shows psammoma bodies and the tumor cells express progesterone receptors. Which of the following is the most common cytogenetic abnormality noted in this tumor?
questions.solution:
The given MRI showing homogeneously enhancing extra - axial, dural based tumor and the microscopic findings are highly suggestive of meningioma. The most common cytogenetic abnormality in meningioma is 22q deletion.

Meningioma is predominantly a benign tumors of adults, usually attached to the dura. It arises from the meningothelial cells of the arachnoid. 50% - 60% of the sporadic meningioma harbors mutations in the NF2 gene (in chromosome 22q12) resulting in the absence of functional merlin protein. In meningioma without NF2 mutations, the most common mutations occur in TNF­ receptor - associated factor 7 (TRAF7).

questions.text: Most common type of fibroid is:
questions.solution:
Interstitial fibroids (intramural) are the most common (75%) type of fibroid. All fibroids are interstitial to begin with.

Fibroids (fibromas or Fibromyomas or leiomyomas) are the most common benign tumours of the uterus. Thy are derived from the smooth muscle of the myometrium and also from blood vessels.

Fibroids are usually well-circumscribed and pseudo-capsulated tumours which on cross-section may show areas of calcification, necrosis with whorled appearance.

questions.text: What is the most common type of choledochal cyst?
questions.solution:
Type I is the most common type of choledochal cyst (75%).

Choledochal cysts are congenital dilations of the intra- and/or extra-hepatic biliary system. 

Related Pearl: Classification of Choledochal Cysts

Type

Feature

Type I

The most common choledochal cyst type; it involves only the extrahepatic biliary tree and is generally a fusiform dilation.

Type II

Saccular diverticulum off the common bile duct and may be mistaken for an accessory gallbladder.

Type III

A cystic dilation of the intramural common bile duct, within the wall of the duodenum, known as choledochoceles.

Type IV

Type IVa: Cysts involving the intrahepatic and extrahepatic biliary tree

Type IVb: Multiple cysts limited to the extrahepatic biliary tree.

Type V

Also known as Caroli disease, involve the intrahepatic ducts only.

questions.text: The most common enzyme deficiency leading to childhood hypertension is ___________
questions.solution:
The most common enzyme deficiency leading to childhood hypertension is 11β-hydroxylase deficiency causing congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH).

Congenital adrenal hyperplasia

Salt-retaining type

(Excessive mineralocorticoids)

Salt-losing type 

(Mineralocorticoid deficiency)

11β-hydroxylase deficiency

17α-hydroxylase deficiency  

21-hydroxylase deficiency

3 β-hydroxysteroid 

dehydrogenase deficiency

Hypernatremia

Hypokalemia

Increased chloride

Hypertension

Hyponatremia

Low chloride

Hyperkalemia

Hypotension

Dehydration

Note:

  • In all forms of CAH, there is a deficiency of glucocorticoid that results in hypoglycemia.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of pancreatic insufficiency in childhood?
questions.solution:
Cystic fibrosis is the most common cause of pancreatic insufficiency in children, which, if untreated, will lead to malnutrition.

Other rare causes include:

  • Shwachman–Diamond syndrome
  • Isolated enzyme deficiencies
  • Chronic pancreatitis
  • Protein-energy malnutrition

Related Pearl: Pancreas - Most Commons

M/C cause of acute pancreatitis: Gallstones

M/C cause of chronic pancreatitis: Alcohol

M/C cause of chronic pancreatitis in children: Cystic fibrosis

M/C cause of pancreatic calcification: Alcohol

M/C congenital variant: Pancreas divisum

M/C site of thrombosis in chronic pancreatitis: Splenic vein 

M/C site of pseudoaneurysm in chronic pancreatitis: Splenic artery

questions.text: The most common cause of death in a lower-middle income country like India is ____________
questions.solution:
Ischemic Heart Disease followed by stroke are the leading causes of death worldwide (overall) as well as in the lower-middle (India), upper-middle and High income group countries.

On the other hand, lower respiratory tract infections followed by diarrhoeal diseases are the leading causes of death in low-income group of countries.

questions.text: A patient presented to the orthopedics​ OPD with ankle sprain caused due to hyper inversion of the right foot. Which of the following ligaments is commonly injured?
questions.solution:
The anterior talofibular ligament is most commonly injured with inversion sprains.

Important ligaments of ankle present on the lateral side, and therefore likely to be injured in inversion sprains include:

  • Anterior talofibular ligament (ATFL) - most commonly injured
  • Posterior talofibular ligament (PTFL)
  • Calcaneofibular ligament (CFL)

The image given below shows the ligaments attached to the lateral side of ankle.

Important ligaments of ankle present on the medial side, and therefore likely to be injured in eversion sprains include:

  • Deltoid ligament (Medial collateral ligament)
  • Spring ligament (calcaneonavicular ligament)

The image given below shows the ligaments attached to the medial side of ankle.

questions.text: Which among the following is the most common primary brain tumor associated with diabetes insipidus?
questions.solution:
Germinomas and pinealomas are the most common primary brain tumors associated with central diabetes insipidus (DI).

Craniopharyngiomas and optic gliomas can also cause central DI when they are very large. 

Other causes for central DI:

  • Congenital: mutations of the vasopressin gene (autosomal-dominant inheritance).
  • Acquired: trauma, neoplasms, autoimmune, infiltrating diseases (Langerhans cell histiocytosis and lymphocytic hypophysitis) and drugs like ethanol, phenytoin, opiate antagonists, halothane, and α-adrenergic agents

questions.text: Which of the following is the commonest type of basal cell carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Nodular type is the commonest type of basal cell carcinoma. Telengiectasia and cystic areas may be present. Some areas may be pigmented.

Histopathological patterns of basal cell carcinoma include:

  • Superficial
  • Nodular
  • Infiltrative
  • Micronodular
  • Pigmented.

questions.text: Leukemia cutis is most commonly seen in association with which of the following malignancies?
questions.solution:
Leukemia cutis is most common in patients with myeloid neoplasms, especially acute myeloid leukemia (AML). The risk is higher with translocation t(8,21).

Leukemia cutis is an infiltration of the skin by myeloid or lymphoid neoplastic leukocytes resulting in clinically identifiable cutaneous lesions. When made up of malignant granulocytic precursor cells, leukemia cutis lesions are also called myeloid sarcoma, granulocytic sarcoma, or chloroma.

Leukemia cutis typically presents as single or multiple monomorphic violaceous, dark‐red or hemorrhagic skin nodules and plaques, especially on the legs, arms, and face.

The image below shows violaceous infiltrated nodules and plaques on the trunk suggestive of leukemia cutis.

questions.text: A woman has been working for a company that manufactures roofing sheets for 12 years, but the company does not provide her with personal protective equipment. Which of the following cancers is commonly seen in such individuals?
questions.solution:
Workers in the roofing industry are exposed to asbestos. Lung cancer (of all histologic types) is the most common cancer associated with asbestos exposure.

Smoking along with asbestos exposure multiplies the risk to a great extent. Cough and hemoptysis are common presentations.

Pleural mesothelioma is the most specific cancer associated with asbestos exposure, but not the most common. Smoking does not seem to be associated with mesothelioma. Pleuritic chest pain or a mass on the radiographic image are common presentations.

questions.text:
Jeevit, a 7-year-old boy brought to you by his mother, complains of bone pain so severe that he cannot sleep. Investigations reveal:

Leukocyte count: 16,000 cells/mm3

Hemoglobin: 6 g/dl

Platelet count: 60,000 cells/mm3

Peripheral smear shows numerous immature blast cells and is suggestive of acute lymphoblastic leukemia

In this age group, which immunophenotype of ALL is most commonly encountered?
questions.solution:
B-lymphoblastic leukemia(pre-B-ALL) is the most common immunophenotype with TdT+,HLA DR+, CD10+, CD19+, CD20+, CD24+, Cy Ig + , with onset at 1-10 years of age.

The most common type of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) in children is B-lymphoblastic leukemia (previously termed pre-B-ALL)

Based on current WHO classification: The most common subtype of ALL is B lymphoblastic leukemia > T lymphoblastic leukemia > Mature B-cell Leukemia (Burkitt leukemia)

The production of symptoms and signs of ALL is a result of the replacement of bone marrow by malignant cells and caused by secondary bone marrow failure. On physical examination, findings of pallor, listlessness, purpuric/petechial skin lesions, or mucous membrane hemorrhage can reflect bone marrow failure. The proliferative nature of the disease may be manifested as lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, or, less often, hepatomegaly. At presentation 75% of patients have leukocyte counts of <20,000/µL; thrombocytopenia is seen in 75% of patients and hepatosplenomegaly in 30–40% of patients. Patients with joint pain may have evidence of joint swelling and effusion. Deep bone pain may be present with marrow involvement, but tenderness will not be elicited.

 

Related Pearl: Immunophenotyping of Acute Lymphocytic Leukemia (ALL)

Type of ALL  Immunophenotype 
Early Pre-B ALL  TdT, DR, CD19, CD24 
Pre B ALL  TdT, DR, CD10, CD19, CD20, CD24, Cy Ig 
Common ALL  CD19+,  CD10+/CALLA+ 
Mature B  ALL  DR, CD19, CD20, CD24, Surface Ig 
Pro-T ALL   CD3, CD7 
Pre-T ALL  TdT, CD2, CD3, CD4, CD5, CD7, CD8, CD34 
Mature T ALL  CD2, CD7, Tdt

questions.text: An epidemic of paralytic poliomyelitis occurs in a non-immune population. Which among the following strains of poliovirus is the most common cause of this?
questions.solution:
Type 1 poliovirus is the most common cause of epidemics in populations.

Poliovirus strains have been classified into 3 types: 

  • Type 1- most common and causes most of the epidemics. 
  • Type 2- endemic infections. 
  • Type 3- epidemics but rarer than type 1. 

Immunity is type-specific. 

Note :- Type 2 is declared eradicated in September, 2015 and Type 3 is declared eradicated in October, 2019

questions.text: What is the most common cause of resistance to acyclovir in HSV-1?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of resistance to acyclovir in HSV-1 is deficient or absent viral thymidine kinase activity.

Viral thymidine kinase is needed in the conversion of acyclovir to acyclovir triphosphate which competitively inhibits the viral DNA polymerase activity.  

Mutation of viral DNA polymerase is rare.

Mechanism of action of anti-viral drugs:

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common type of anal fistula?
questions.solution:
The most common anal fistula is the intersphincteric fistula.

A fistula-in-ano is an abnormal hollow tract or cavity that is lined with granulation tissue and that connects a primary opening inside the anal canal to a secondary opening in the perianal skin. The most common cause is a perianal abscess. Other causes include tuberculosis or Crohn's disease.

Symptoms:

  • Perianal pain
  • Discharge- intermittent purulent discharge (which may be bloody) 

Goodsall’s rule can be used as a guide in determining the location of the internal opening of the fistula.

  • Fistulas with an external opening anteriorly connect to the internal opening by a short, radial tract.
  • Fistulas with an external opening posteriorly track in a curvilinear fashion to the posterior midline.

Exceptions to Goodsall’s Rule

However, exceptions to this rule often occur: Fistulas with an anterior external opening greater than 3 cm from the anal margin usually track to the posterior midline.

Investigations:

The investigations done for fistula-in-ano are as follows:

  • Fistulogram
  • Endoanal ultrasound
  • MRI
  • Computed tomography (CT) scan
  • Endocoil MRI
  • Hydrogen peroxide–enhanced 3-D endoanal ultrasonography

An MRI is the gold standard investigation for fistula imaging. It helps us to identify the secondary extensions of the track, which when missed may cause persistence of the fistula. (Option-A)

Treatment:

  • Control of constipation
  • Sitz bath
  • Fistulotomy
  • Fistulectomy
  • Ligation of intersphincteric fistula tract (LIFT)
  • Setons
  • Advancement flaps

Related Pearl: Park's classification of fistula–in–ano

 Type of Fistula

Arises due to 

Begins from

Track

Ends in

Inter-sphincteric

Perianal abscess

Dentate line

In inter-sphincteric space

Perianal skin or perineum

Trans- sphincteric

Ischiorectal Fossa abscess

Dentate line

Crosses the internal and external sphincters 

Perineal skin or perineum

Supra- sphincteric

Supra-levator abscess

Dentate line

Penetrates the inter-sphincteric space, continues above puborectalis, and penetrates levator ani

Perineal skin or perineum

Extra- sphincteric

Penetrating injury

Crohn’s disease

Carcinoma rectum

 Rectum or sigmoid colon 

Outside the external sphincter, penetrating the levator ani 

 Peri-anal skin via ischio-rectal  fossa.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common psychiatric comorbidity that you would expect to find in a patient with anorexia nervosa?
questions.solution:
Depression is the most common psychiatric comorbidity seen in patients with anorexia nervosa.

Overall, anorexia nervosa is associated with depression in 65% of cases, social phobia in 35% of cases, and obsessive-compulsive disorder in 25% of cases.

questions.text: What is the most common source of loose bodies in the knee joint?
questions.solution: Almost 50 % of the loose bodies arise from osteochondritis dissecans. The source is unknown in nearly 33% of the cases and osteophytes and damaged menisci contribute to only a few cases.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of death in patients who undergo bariatric surgery?
questions.solution:
Pulmonary embolism is the most common cause of death in patients of bariatric surgery.

Pathogenesis:

Obesity
 ↓ 
Increased levels of plasminogen activator inhibitor-1
 ↓ 
Blocks conversion of plasminogen to plasmin
 ↓ 
Decreased fibrinolytic activity
 ↓ 
Hypercoagulable state
 ↓ 
Increased risk for VTE

Morbidly obese patients are physically inactive. Restricted mobility post-surgery potentiates this risk of developing deep vein thrombosis. 

Note: Most common cause of death in bariatric surgery is DVT/pulmonary embolism. Most common complication of bariatric surgery is an anastomotic leak

questions.text: What is the most common fetal injury associated with caesarean section?
questions.solution:
Skin laceration is the most common fetal injury associated with caesarean section. Other injuries seen include:

  • Cephalohematoma
  • Brachial plexus injury
  • Clavicular fracture
  • Skull fracture
  • Facial nerve palsy

questions.text: A middle-aged non-smoker presented with a dry persistent cough and hemoptysis. A CT scan showed a mass in the periphery of his right lung. A biopsy was taken, cells showed an acinar pattern with mucin formation. The cells were positive for thyroid transcription factor 1 and napsin A. What other feature is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the biopsy findings is suggestive of lung adenocarcinoma. It is most commonly associated with hypertrophic osteoarthropathy.

Adenocarcinomas are mainly seen in the periphery of the lung. They grow in various patterns like acinar, lepidic, papillary, micropapillary, and solid with mucin formation. Cells are positive for markers like thyroid transcription factor 1 and napsin A.

Option C: Hypercalcemia due to ectopic production of PTH-related peptide is seen in squamous cell carcinoma.

Options B and D: However, SIADH, Cushing’s syndrome, Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome are associated with small-cell lung carcinoma.

Related Pearl: Paraneoplastic Syndromes and Underlying Cancers

Neural tumours

ACTH: Adrenocorticotropic hormone

questions.text: A 55-year-old chronic smoker was brought to the emergency room with complaints of fever, cough with expectoration, difficulty in breathing since the past one day. He gives a history of progressive and persistent symptoms since the last 4 years. Earlier PFT findings showed reduced FEV1 and increased RV but normal diffusion capacity. The most common bacteria causing this condition is:
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario gives a picture of acute exacerbation of COPD. H.influenzae is the most common bacterial cause of acute exacerbation of COPD.

Moraxella is the second most common bacterial cause of acute exacerbation of COPD. Staph aureus and pneumococcus are rarely involved in acute exacerbation of COPD.

questions.text: The most common cause of death in battered baby syndrome is:
questions.solution:
The most common cause of death in battered baby syndrome is head injury followed by rupture of abdominal organ.

The classic head injury associated with battered children is subdural hematoma.

questions.text: Most common arrhythmia seen during laparoscopy is:
questions.solution:
Most common arrhythmia created by laparoscopy is bradycardia.

A rapid stretch of the peritoneal membrane often causes a vagovagal response with bradycardia and occasionally hypotension.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of death in patients undergoing chronic dialysis?
questions.solution:
Cardiovascular disease due to accelerated atherosclerosis is the major cause of death in patients with ESRD on chronic dialysis.

Cardiovascular mortality is higher in dialysis patients compared to patients after transplantation.

questions.text: A patient who was diagnosed with meningitis is on chloramphenicol therapy. Which of the following blood dyscrasias as a side effect of this drug?
questions.solution:
The patient is most likely to have aplastic anemia, as it is the most common blood dyscrasia associated with the use of chloramphenicol. It can lead to fatal pancytopenia that has a high rate of mortality. 

Hematological toxicities of chloramphenicol include:

  • Dose-related toxicity - pancytopenia (anemia, thrombocytopenia, leukopenia)
  • Idiosyncratic response - aplastic anemia

Blood dyscrasias occurring with chloramphenicol:

  • Aplastic anemia (70%)
  • Hypoplastic anemia
  • Agranulocytosis
  • Thrombocytopenia

Chloramphenicol remains an alternative drug for the treatment of meningitis caused by H. influenzae, N. meningitidis, and S. pneumoniae in developing countries and also in patients who have a severe allergy to β-lactams.

questions.text: What is the most common manifestation of Neisseria meningitidis infection?
questions.solution:
Infection with Neisseria meningitidis is most commonly asymptomatic colonization in the nasopharynx of healthy individuals. Hence, a nasopharyngeal swab is used in the detection of carriers. In some patients, local inflammation ensues with rhinitis and pharyngitis. 

Ceftriaxone as a single-dose IV/IM injection is highly (97%) effective in the eradication of carrier state and can be used at all ages and also in pregnancy. Ciprofloxacin is also highly effective and can be given orally, but it is not recommended in pregnancy and below 18 years of age.

questions.text: Which of the following ovarian tumors is the most radiosensitive?
questions.solution: Dysgerminoma is the most radiosensitive ovarian tumor. They are highly susceptible to radiotherapy.

questions.text: The most common chronic disease leading to anemia in pregnancy is ________
questions.solution:
Chronic renal insufficiency is the most common disorder encountered as a cause of anemia during pregnancy.

Recombinant erythropoietin is used in treating anaemia due to chronic renal failure.
